title: International Space Station: Launching NASA and Humanity into Deep Space
summary: Curiosity and the desire to explore are traits deeply rooted in human nature. Space exploration is no exception; it reflects humanity’s timeless drive to seek new horizons, challenge our limits, and understand our universe. The advancements of modern civilization—from the electricity that powers our homes to basic hygienic breakthroughs that ensure our health— happened thanks […]
detailed_news: In November 2025, NASA and its international partners will surpass 25 years of continuous human presence aboard the International Space Station. As NASA prepares for Artemis missions to the Moon and sets sights on Mars, the space station continues to enable groundbreaking research not possible on Earth. The space station provides a testbed to refine these systems before human’s travel to distant destinations. Astronauts aboard the space station have collected photographs to document Earth’s surface through Crew Earth Observations. Now, those same techniques are being adapted for Artemis II , where astronauts will use handheld cameras to capture images of the Moon. Researchers have also advanced 3D printing in space , enabling astronauts to make tools and parts on-demand. Measurements taken on Artemis II crew will expand a repository of human health data. NASA researchers hope to use this data repository to develop protocols aimed at keeping astronauts healthy on missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond. Organ-chip research could improve crew prevention measures and create personalized medical treatments for humans, on Earth and in space.

title: Making High Fidelity Fluxgate Cores for Space Science and Space Weather Missions
summary: A NASA-sponsored team at the University of Iowa (UI) is restoring and advancing the nation’s capability to make high-fidelity magnetic field measurements needed to investigate space weather that can impact our communication and power grids on Earth and our assets in space.
detailed_news: NASA-sponsored team at the University of Iowa is restoring and advancing the nation's capability to make high-fidelity magnetic field measurements. Fluxgate magnetometers are widely-used space science and space weather instruments. The ferromagnetic cores are produced starting from base metal powders that are melted into custom alloys, rolled into thin foils. The SWIM sensor can also be manufactured with a lightweight carbon-composite cover (or the cover can be omitted) to achieve a sensor mass of ~110 g. Using three smaller cores with improved metallurgy instead of six large racetrack cores reduced the power consumption by a factor of two. The MAGIC electronics use a traditional analog demodulator fluxgate and magnetic feedback design.

title: SpaceX intensifies testing to ready Pad 2 at Starbase

authors.name: Alejandro Alcantarilla Romera and Chris Bergin

summary:
SpaceX is ramping up testing of its second launch pad at Starbase, conducting multiple checkouts…
The post SpaceX intensifies testing to ready Pad 2 at Starbase appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is ramping up testing of its second launch pad at Starbase, conducting multiple checkouts of the water deluge system. The flurry of activity highlights the company’s push toward operational readiness for Pad 2, including enhancements to water management and structural protections. The pad is set to host its first launch during Flight 12 of Starship in 2026. Pad 2 at Starbase is ramping up its testing ahead of hosting the next version of Starship, starting with Flight 12 next year. A key advantage over Pad 1 is the potential for same-day retests following an abort. Pad 2’s setup allows for quicker recovery and retry once the issue is resolved. The “Megabunker’ has emerged at the old launch site entrance. It resembles a fortified medieval fortress, sparking speculation about its purpose. Experts suggest it may house critical electronics and control equipment for pad operations. The next step involves fitting flex hoses to link the quick disconnects to ground systems.

Estonia marked its first 10 years as an ESA Member State. Exoplanet-tracking Plato spacecraft arrived at ESTEC Test Centre in the Netherlands for testing.

title: Gaia discovers our galaxy’s great wave
summary: Our Milky Way galaxy never sits still: it rotates and wobbles. And now, data from the European Space Agency’s Gaia space telescope reveal that our galaxy also has a giant wave rippling outwards from its centre.
detailed_news: Since the 1950s, we've known that the Milky Way's disc is warped. Then in 2020 Gaia discovered that this disc wobbles over time. And now it has become clear that a great wave stirs the motion of stars in our galaxy over distances of tens of thousands of light-years from the Sun. ‘This observed behaviour is consistent with what we would expect from a wave,’ says Eloisa Poggio from INAF in Italy. Young giant stars and Cepheids move with the wave. It is possible that young stars retain the memory of the wave information from the gas itself, from which they were born. Scientists do not know the origin of these galactic shakes. A past collision with a dwarf galaxy could be a possible explanation.

title: No Deal Yet To Avert Shutdown Tomorrow Night
summary: President Trump and congressional leaders left their meeting at the White House this afternoon with no deal to avert a government shutdown at midnight tomorrow night. If nothing changes, agencies […]
detailed_news: President Trump and congressional leaders left their meeting at the White House this afternoon with no deal to avert a government shutdown at midnight tomorrow night. If nothing changes, agencies like NASA will have to pause all non-essential operations at 12:01 am Wednesday after FY2025 ends with no appropriations for FY2026. House Republicans passed a “clean” Continuing Resolution (CR) on September 19 to keep the government operating at full strength through November 21. The House can pass legislation with a simple majority, but the Senate needs 60 votes to pass this type of bill. Shutdowns are caused by a lapse in appropriations and impact activities funded in the 12 appropriations bills. During a shutdown, essential operations including those to protect life and property continue, although workers are not paid until the shutdown ends. At NASA, operations of the International Space Station, for example, will not be affected.

title: Report claims NASA taking illegal steps to implement budget proposal
summary:

The post Report claims NASA taking illegal steps to implement budget proposal appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Senate Democrats say NASA is taking steps in to carry out the administration's proposed budget. The budget proposal sought a nearly 25% cut in NASA’s overall budget in 2026. Appropriations bills pending in the House and Senate largely reject that cut. The report comes as NASA and the rest of the federal government faces a potential shutdown. Jeff Foust has a Ph.D. in planetary sciences from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He also has a bachelor’s degree with honors in geophysics and planetary science... title: Ground testing anomaly destroys Firefly Aerospace’s Alpha booster intended for next flight
summary: The anomaly came about a month after the FAA issued a Return to Flight determination for Firefly’s Alpha rockets following an anomaly experienced during Alpha Flight 6 in April.
detailed_news: The booster designated for Alpha Flight 7 “experienced an event that resulted in a loss of the stage,” the company said in a statement. A week before the incident, CEO Jason Kim said he expected Firefly to resume launches in the “coming weeks” Firefly Aerospace launched its Alpha rocket Friday after a launch attempt on Wednesday was scrubbed by bad weather. During Flight 4, also known as “Fly the Lightning,” Firefly saw a guidance, navigation and control (GNC) issue on the rocket’s second stage that prevented it from achieving its planned orbit.

title: Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 launches Starlink and Kuiper satellites
summary:
SpaceX is scheduled to launch up to three times this week, with each mission planned…
The post Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 launches Starlink and Kuiper satellites appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is scheduled to launch up to three times this week, with each mission planned to deploy internet communications satellites into low-Earth orbit. China kicked off the week’s launch manifest, for those in UTC, with the launch of its 100th Chang Zheng 2D rocket in the early hours of Monday morning. SpaceX will launch its third and final batch of satellites for Amazon’s Project Kuiper constellation. The mission is currently set to liftoff on Friday, Oct. 3, at 11:43 PM EDT (06:30 UTC on October 4), in the middle of a short 27-minute launch window. Onboard will be 28 more Starlink v2 Mini satellites, bound for an orbit at an altitude of 595 km, inclined at 53 degrees. Booster B1097 will make its second flight, having debuted only weeks ago at the start of September, launching a mission for Starlink's Group 17 shell.  NASASpaceflight.com will be taking part in the 25th anniversary of the first space shuttle mission in September 2025. The space shuttle program will take part in a series of missions over the course of 15 years. The first mission will take place on September 22, 2025, with the second and final mission scheduled for September 23, 2025.

Adam of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, presented the topic titled “Surface Science in Microgravity – Fluid Geometry in the Ring-Sheared Drop,” presented to a broad audience from academia and the scientific community during the Physical Sciences and Materials Development session. Dr. Adam provided a […]
detailed_news: The Ring Sheared Drop (RSD) enables researchers to isolate shear-induced aggregation processes relevant to neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The RSD's custom camera configuration has enabled a novel fluid characterization technique known as Particle Tracking Velocimetry (PTV)

title: Hubble Surveys Cloudy Cluster
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image released on Sept. 12, 2025, features a cloudy starscape from an impressive star cluster. This scene is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. With a mass equal to 10–20% of the mass of the Milky Way, the Large […]
detailed_news: The Large Magellanic Cloud is a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away. It is home to several massive stellar nurseries where gas clouds coalesce into new stars. This image marries observations made roughly 20 years apart, a testament to Hubble’s longevity.

title: Astronaut Candidates Get to Work at Johnson Space Center
summary: NASA announced its newest class of astronaut candidates on Sept. 22, 2025, at the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. After the welcome ceremony, the 10 highly qualified individuals rolled up their sleeves and prepared for the next step in their journey to the stars: nearly two years of training to become flight-eligible for missions […]
detailed_news: NASA announced its newest class of astronaut candidates on Sept. 22, 2025. They will undergo nearly two years of training to become flight-eligible for missions to low Earth orbit, the Moon, and ultimately, Mars. Each candidate will receive flight training, learning to pilot or improving their current piloting skills through the T-38 supersonic jet. Many members of NASA’s active astronaut corps emphasize that the learning does not stop when astronaut candidate training ends. As NASA astronaut Frank Rubio, class mentor, told the group, “You’ll become part of a legacy of those who trained before you, continuing the adventure they started”

title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Studies Moon-Forming Disk Around Massive Planet
summary: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disk encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disk surrounding the world called CT Cha b, which is located 625 light-years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons, although no moons are […]
detailed_news: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disk encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disk surrounding the world called CT Cha b, which is located 625 light-years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons. Webb is an international program led by NASA with its partners, ESA (European Space Agency) and CSA (Canadian Space Agency). Webb is solving mysteries in our solar system, looking beyond to distant worlds around other stars. To learn more about Webb, visit: https://science.nasa.gov/webb

title: Webb studies moon-forming disc around massive planet
summary: The NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disc encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disc surrounding the world called CT Cha B, which is located 625 light years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons, although no moons are detected in the Webb data. The disc offers insight into how the moons of Solar System gas giants like Jupiter might have formed.
detailed_news: The carbon-rich disc surrounding the world called CT Cha B, which is located 625 light years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons. The disc offers insight into how the moons of Solar System gas giants like Jupiter might have formed. Our Solar System contains eight major planets, and more than 400 known moons orbiting six of these planets. In the coming year, the team will use Webb to perform a comprehensive survey of similar objects to better understand the diversity of physical and chemical properties in the discs around young planets. The insights could be useful as our Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ( Juice ) makes its way to Jupiter, and as we prepare a future mission to orbit and land on Saturn's moon Enceladus.
